description: Linda Mahoney McVey  shared  Brad Snyder 's  photo . So true, and so sad!  Lol

YOU KNOW YOU'RE FROM ARIZONA WHEN. . .   1. You can say Hohokam and no one thinks you're making it up.     2.You no longer associate rivers or bridges with water.    ...  3.You know that a "swamp cooler" is not a happy hour drink.     4.You can contemplate a high temperature of 120 degrees as "not all that bad, after all it's a dry heat."     5.You know that you can make sun tea outside faster than instant tea in your microwave.     6.You have to run your air conditioner in the middle of winter so that you can use your fireplace.     7.The water coming from the "cold" tap is hotter than that from the hot" tap.     8.You can correctly pronounce the following words: "Saguaro", "Tempe", "Gila Bend", "San Xavier del Bac", "Canyon de Chelly", "Mogollon Rim", "Cholla", and "Tlaquepacque", "Ajo".     9.It's noon on a weekday in July, kids are on summer vacation, and not one single person is moving on the streets.     10.Hot air balloons can't fly because the air outside is hotter than the air inside.     11.You buy salsa by the gallon.     12.Your Christmas decorations include a half a yard of sand and 100 paper bags.     13.You think someone driving while wearing oven mitts is clever.     14.Most of the restaurants in your town have the first name "El" or "Los."     15.You think six tons of crushed rock makes a beautiful yard.     16.You can say 115 degrees without fainting.     17.Vehicles with open windows have the right-of-way in the summer.     18.People break out coats when the temperature drops below 70.     19.You discover, in July, it only takes two fingers to drive your car.     20.The pool can be warmer than you are.     21.You realize Valley Fever isn't a disco dance.     22.People with black cars or have black upholstery in their car are automatically assumed to be from out-of-state or nuts.     23.You know better than to get into a car/truck with leather seats if you're wearing shorts.    24.Announcements for Fourth of July events always end with "in case of monsoon..."     25.You have to explain to out-of-staters why there is no daylight savings time     26.You can say "haboob" without giggling. description: AJ+ Patrick is a 27-year-old student. Harry is an 89-year-old retiree. They’re roommates. Judson Smart Living William Letmon Joshua Rodriguez Yanira Torres Amy Huber Barbara Rowe-Pryde

comments.content: Judson Smart Living  in Cleveland, Ohio, also offers complimentary housing to students for an intergenerational cultural experience.  http://www.judsonsmartliving.org/.../intergenerational.../
This is brilliant

not long ago in many societies the whole family lived together (2-3 generations under the same roof). Economic, personal and technological changes made the old family idea a thing of the past. I think the Netherlands project is positive, there is the companionship aspect but also the passing on of knowledge (wisdom) that probably otherwise it would be lost.

Glad to be African, Kenyan for that matter. We take care of our old parents/grandparents. They come live with us when there too old or we find a young care giver to live with them. It's sad to see how others just abandon their old parents and never care for them, don't you know you will get old one day? Do you want your kids forgetting about you in a nursing home??
It's incredibly unhealthy the way we self-segregate in this country according to so many superficial differences, age being one of them.

When I was in 3rd grade our teacher had us go visit the nursing home once a month and do a project with the residents there. It's was by far the most impact full thing a teacher ever did in a class. I never saw family visiting their parents, grandparen ... See More

I live in Tulsa, OK and a local nursing home in one of the suburbs has a kindergarten school within their nursing home. The kids are of course just adored by the residents and they have craft and physical activity times together between lessons. The el ... See More

I volunteer at the urgent care in a hospital and the elder patients are the best! I love helping them out! I finish my shift every week with a smile and the more interactions I have with the patients the better my day gets 💞  I would totally do something like this 😆

Aw just lightens my heart no end.  What a wonderful man you are Patrick and all the others like you out there. I hope you know you're all so special and I can see too how much Harry values your relationship and thinks you're kinda special too. Our unsung heroes.
William Letmon . How cool what can be accomplished when a country cares about its old and young and is not interested in making them soldiers and haters

I saw this a while ago. I think it is an excellent idea, that we should try here. From our kids experience it is expensive to get accommodation. And living with other hard partying students isn't for everyone. This could be great.
I choose this any day over the hedonistic, boisterous and mindless folk who bombard existence with their recklessness, moral vacuity, and directionlessness in life.

I started out as an Aide at a nursing home, I am now the charge nurse. I absolutely love working with the elderly. In Jamaica we keep our parent/ grandparents at home until they die. I was so shocked when I see kids don't ever come see there parents un ... See More

wow!! how awesome, is something like here in Mexico, we have high respect for our old folks end have great regard for them also most of the families have elder people living with them and young guys learn from/since an early age that life is also getting old and that death will always be a constant part of life since birth.

It really is a wonderful concept. In their later years elderly people find themselves lonely. This arrangement is a welcome step and a win win situation for the elders and the youngsters who get to live rent free and learn life lessons.
I would so do this in s heart beat! Older folks can be hella cool, and their stories are interesting. So much to be learned from those who have lived through so much  💖
This is what a sane caring society offers its citizens.  It comes up with creative ways to improve the lives of both young and old.

My room mate, she's 75, she cool, funny and full of knowledge. We just made caveman chili and its so funny cause by the time I got my 1st bowl she told me she already had 3. Ha! I found that so funny.

I can't praise this concept enough..!! Bridging the generational gap, caring for and respecting ones elders, the passing of wisdom and experience through shared life events, in burdening youth to study with more focus and less fear of debt...
How strange it is. We have family members at home and yet we don't build such connections with them yet we are okay building up relations with total strangers living in an old home.  :/

I would highly recommend this. I use to live with 96years old lady for an almost a year. We were roommates and we both benefited and enjoyed the stay. Our lifes seperated when she died. But I will always remember that part of my life.

This is is a great idea. I work in a nursing home as a CNA. This would improve a residents quality of life. Children who "drop off" their parents in home give up on them and the parent gives up. Your parents gave their life taking care of you, you shou ... See More

Until the early 1900s, people stayed close to where they were born and many homes were multigenerational meaning children, parents and grand parents all lived under one roof. You can conceive of it being a beautiful way for children to grow up but I suspect that more often than not is was a lifetime of hell. But kids knew their grandparents and the grandparents were never alone like they are now.

Joshua Rodriguez  This is amazing! So far o have heard the following about the Netherlands  1. Few people in prison b/c of lg rehabilitation rates. 2. Great maternity leave - longer with more salary.  ... See More
This is amazing! So many older people are so lonely, spending 30 hours a week with someone can make life so much more worth living and the student gets free accommodation- - it's a win win

Having worked in a nursing home when I was 13, I know how these elder people feel. I often made me sad to see them being "left to die alone". Creating a nurturing relationship with young people gave them such happiness, so I have to say that this idea is just beautiful!

What a fantastic idea!  I'd say they'd need to screen applicants very carefully here in the US but it makes sense that each group is really benefiting from the arrangement and I love the fact that it's you know intergenerational and keeps him these folks engaged with younger you know people on a daily basis so I think it's great
Amazing idea!!  I'm a 55 year old widow and have 3 college girls living with me. I never have to be alone and I love hearing their little stories, it takes me back to my magical college days!

You know...my moms been telling me to move in with an older lady. She's like find an older lady who's lonely and is willing to rent you a room and that way you can have your independence while also keeping company and just being helpful to someone that could really use it...i was like ok mom...I'll go pick an old lady at the grocery store lol  Yanira Torres  look!!

My 2 year son (then) will share the remote control of the tv with my Grandpa and rub on his bald head, he visits us from México once every two years and my son will cry and miss him,and he asks to bring him back to stay with him. (My grandpa is 92 already,too much to travel and too scary to go there) our kids see how we take care of each other in the Family,I hope they keep that feeling)

I have worked with seniors in different avenues. I love being with them. They love to tell you tales of their fascinating lifestyle. My last job after I retired working for Home Instead at the house of these wonderful people. A little cooking. A little house chores and pure companionships. Even the cranky seniors need friendship. This is great program to get together. Love it.

I can undertand completely and know exactly what their close relationship is. Breaks my heart, he will be crushed if anything happens to his older friend. I know this myself.  As I have lost my friend of over 22 odd years and am finding it very extremely hard.

Yes we need to do things like this here...but of course here is ALL about taking what money Elders have left for their care. There is not enough time in one day for all the nurses to spend more than a few minutes with the Elderly...very sad. One time w ... See More

God I love this!! Then maybe college dorms could be known for sleeping and studying a little more... And a way not to forget the generation that built us... Oh the things that could be learned... The stories.... Raising a compassionate generation... Hmmm???

I always come to look at these wonderful stories and curious to see how many people clicked the "angry" button. I'm over here like, "why ya mad bro!?" I don't see how these kinds of stories can piss people off

Wow awsome .. my grandparents raised me since I was 3 and I never moved out !!  U can call it spoiled ..I'll take that ..but it taught me so much .. and I took care of my 94 year old grampa ( basically daddy) until he passed 2 years ago .. I would do i ... See More

I love this! I am 61 and disabled. I love one block from Kansas State University and must have roommates to stay here. It has been quite an experience, living with young male college kids and a 30 yr old Army vet. Feeling relieved to have a 38 yr old female roommate now

That is totally awesome. I would have done that while in Uni. I love spending time with seniors, you can learn so much. As a history graduate this would have been fabulous to have all those primary sources who witnessed history first hand.

Good idea. Potential for abuse of all sorts aside, still a good concept. I'm thinking about Wills being changed. Executors being changed, power of attorney, etc. There would have to be rules or manipulation could be rampant.

We could use this in America, though students probably wouldn't be as caring as the one here in this video  :/  In the US, we are taught to respect our elders but what's the point if we throw them away in some home and leave them to wallow in abuse and loneliness?

We have a huge seniors home with a day care too in Toronto.  Lots of young children don't have grandparents so they love the attention and the seniors love watching, eating and seeing the young ones. I worked there for a few years and it was a super experience.  😃

My grandmother was my favorite person in the world. My mom is awesome but my G-Ma was very special to me. Never to busy for me and only a few homes over on my block. From an early age through my tean years I would sit with her for hours or help her in  ... See More

Thank you Nicole Musicco. It's so beautiful that it made me cry! I wish we had a programme like this! It makes so much sense. A fabulous way to integrate people of all ages. And yes, take it from me, the elderly do become a part of you!  ❤️

This is a GREAT idea! Not only do the students learn all kinds of things from their new "grandparents," but they also offer CHANGE and 'freshness' to the residents who may not be able to get out and experience much of that anymore. We should so do this in this country! Plus, it's a pretty quiet environment for studying.  ;-)

This is freaking brilliant!!! What a way to teach young people compassion and humility and provide the aging with a companion! Canada should look into this. I mean with tuition being so expensive this would be an amazing option to save money for students and provide one of our most neglected healthcare areas with a flow of good people

I would definitely do this for free housing! It costs so much and you learn while doing it in multiple ways. Not to mention the connections you make and how they make them happier for it. I think this should be implemented throughout the public University systems to cut down on the cost of schools and elderly care homes.
Amy Huber  - I thought about you and your studies when I saw this video earlier. It seems like a really cool idea and beneficial to everyone involved. Would love to hear what you think about it.  😄

Thanks for this  Barbara Rowe-Pryde . Kathy has spent a lot of time recuperating in places like this and I always enjoyed mealtimes with these older folks. Never boring, always engaging, ever thoughtful visits.

Kim Sexton- The school my oldest son Nathan goes to is in Prescott. (ERAU) he's been in student apartments for 2.5 years now, and they rent it out separately. His first year and a half his roommate was an older guy with a walker. They got along fine!  Now he has another student in there, but year to year he doesn't know who it is!  He graduates in December.

Brilliant idea!  👍  Would definitely like to see this happen in Australia. There's so much benefit to gain from each other in this kind if environment. I just hope the application process is thorough and demands police clearances and background checks on the young applicants. Last thing you want is for some mental case to move in with people that are so venerable.

description: Linda Mahoney McVey  shared  Chris Blackburn 's  post . My nephew  Chris Blackburn  was asked to represent his company at these games.  He had a choice of the summer games or the para-olympics and he chose these!  So proud of him and happy for his experience.

Chris Blackburn I've been lucky enough in my lifetime to attend an OSU vs. Michigan football game, numerous March Madness Games, an NBA final game, a MLB playoff game of my favorite team, and a World Cup soccer match, and yet last night attending the Paralympics Opening Ceremony in Rio was by far my best sporting experience.    I witnessed the definition of courage in Marcia Malsar, one of the torch bearers last night.  Marcia, because of a disease, must use a walking cane to stand and walk.  Last night while carrying the torch, Marcia fell on live TV and in front of thousands at the opening ceremony due to the rain.  Then, as if her legs were that of an ox, and to the roar of the crowd, stood on her own, grabbed the torch, and marched on to the chants of "Never give up."  You need a new  hero in life, look her up.  I witnessed a miracle in front of my own eyes.  Last night's flag bearers were 8 children, all of whom previously could not walk.  However due to special shoes and clothes, were propped by their parents and walked in front of millions to raise the Paralympic flag.  Amazing moment to see and a very emotional moment. Chris Blackburn
